snippet.textDisplay:
Thanks Rick & Jack.
So, so sad.
You've certainly summed-up how I'm feeling.
I never met him. I had no relationship with him. Yet I am profoundly upset by Neil's death.
It is an old cliché, but their music is the soundtrack to my life - but, more than that, Neil's lyrics, no, wordsmanship, are an intrinsic part of my very being. They are interwoven in my thoughts & deeds.
Devastated.
RIP Neil

snippet.textDisplay: As a proud Canadian, a drummer and a lifelong Rush fan, I’m devastated at the passing of Neil Peart. He was the ultimate personification of musical talent. His legacy will endure through the ages. I am eternally grateful for his immense contribution to music and for being an major influence in my formative years as a young drummer. RIP Neil. “The proper function of man is to live, not to exist. I shall not waste my days in trying to prolong them. I shall use my time.” - Neil Peart

snippet.textDisplay: Most people incarnate, and leave very little impact, they have children perhaps, their name is carved on a tombstone, but eventually their name fades into history. Neil Peart, that name will truly echo in eternity, uttered with reverence for time immemorial, his legacy lives on, Imagine the Rush tribute concert that happens in 2112. He made a mark equal of great figures of history, whatever reason he was put on this planet, he fulfilled that purpose, and then some. I hope Neil, that the outpouring of millions of people around the globe, these words of condolence, these messages of love and utmost respect, find their way to you, in whatever reality you now inhabit, as a magnificent wave of pure conscious love. I hope your destination is as magical and wondrous as that which you gave to us. Farewell, to Kings.....

snippet.textDisplay:
Like Rick I am profoundly saddened by this news. I grew up as a British army child in Germany in the 70’s and early 80’s and my brother introduced me to Rush with Hemispheres. Moving around a lot the comfort that he and I got from just being able to sit down with our vinyl LPs and listen to the amazing trio and read the lyrics on the album notes gave us hours of discussion about what they meant and how they affected us at a basic level. Even as young kids we knew that this band were something special and it was a perfect melding of outstanding musicians coupled to deep, meaningful and sometimes just perfect song lyrics.

The professor touched so many lives, influenced so many people and made two snotty army brats very happy, for that I thank him from the bottom of my soul

“When all around is madness and there’s no safe port in view, I long to turn my path homeward and stop a while with you”

RIP Neil

snippet.textDisplay: This news totally floored me. I grew up in Toronto listening and Loving Rush... I've followed them since I was 10 years old in 1975. They were my first rock concert in T.O.. I was hooked... over the years I was fortunate to see them play 14 times throughout my life. We lost a great man and will forever be a legend  not just Rock , but in all music. I've always said what a CLASSY BAND RUSH IS... And I'm so proud of all the people I've been able to inspire to listen to and love this great band.  Neil your music and words  will live on forever and I  know how lucky I am to have had the opportunity to love everything you put out there. RIP.

snippet.textDisplay:
Working Man was my first favorite Rush Song too! Funny and heartwarming story about the fan letter. All the outpouring of grief and appreciation not only on this video and in this comment section, which is substantial but ACROSS the music world from Styx to Foo Fighters, to Tool, to thousands of other artists, it's so very clear Neil Peart was such a positive influence on so many people. To see these heartfelt messages of tribute and of goodbye is a form of beauty in the face of tragedy. During Rush's career they were often met with obstacles. Labels didn't want to sign them, radio stations didn't want to play them, and fans were made fun for liking them too. It was often ridiculed as "Nerd Rock", "Loser Music", or "What the virgin smart kids listen too". I've heard it all in my time but the fact is: Rush is one of the top 5 rock bands of all time bar none. Often called the Canadian Led Zeppelin (while many would argue they were better than Zeppelin) Every single member of the band was ultra talented but Neil Peart in my humble opinion, was the best of them all. Not only was he the greatest drummer alive, he wrote the lyrics. I'll leave you with my favorite Neil Peart lyric:


"And the men who hold high places
Must be the ones to start
To mold a new reality
Closer to the Heart"

As true now as it was then. It's what I call an Evergreen lyric, it will never grow old. Much like the discography of Rush.


Rest in peace Neil. A great lyricist, great drummer, a great human. You will be missed, but never forgotten.

snippet.textDisplay: Here in Canada I think everyone was just born knowing of Rush especially Subdivision and Tom Sawyer. As a teen in the early 1980s I "discovered" Rush and listened to Grace Under Pressure on cassette. At the time is was one of the few albums where I listened to every song. For me the lyrics stood out more than anything the band musically worked so well together I never really thought of each band member separately. I too was shocked at the news of Neil's death since it didn't seem to be well known he was ill. I certainly have many found memories of listening to Rush thanks to Geddy, Alex and Neil.

snippet.textDisplay: The fans' outpouring of grief over Neil Peart makes me cringe-and I am an avowed 35 year fan of him and Rush. The artists, agents, executives and managers at the highest level of the business are mercenary, cut throat, greedy and soulless and these are the moments when it is exposed yet the fans can't see it.  People are saying that Rush are 'like a family' and that they won't tour without NP. Well we'll just wait and see. I wouldn't bet the farm on it. Just like Steely Dan went straight out on tour within weeks of Walter Becker dying you'll find Lee and Lifeson are a lot less sentimental than you expect. They will probably be out on tour with a 'replacement' as there's plenty who are capable, Minneman/Blundell/Gavin Harrison etc. The fans will be forced to accept it and the PR machine/Press will say they possibly sound 'even better'. Toto, The Who have replaced 'irreplaceable' drummers and Queen, Fleetwood Mac, The Eagles have even done the same with iconic vocalists in Mercury/Buckingham/Frey. Just red pilling you folks so you don't have to be so shocked when it happens. Come back and thank me later.

Neil “Pratt” Peart... along with Lerxst and Dirk were a huge part of my musical landscape growing up... I can still remember with spine tingling realism the first time, at age 16 in 1974 hearing Working Man for the first time.
I was hooked and managed to see RUSH live 24 times.
Cheer Rick... you’re doing a world of good memorializing Neil and for that I will always be greatful to you, you’re a good man!

snippet.textDisplay:
Count me among the rest of us who are profoundly sad and heartbroken. Neil is the reason I picked up drumsticks as a kid. I spent countless hours trying to play along (and thinking I could), but I’d usually just stop playing and bask in the awesomeness. I still do. But, I’m still trying, and he would appreciate that. He said’ “What is a master but a master student?”

I credit him for my love of the drum kit, and also for influencing my appreciation for freedom of though, and love of reading.

As you guys said - what a hugely likable person he was, above all. There have been and still are many drummers that are insanely talented, but not many at all with his intelligence, humility, and SENSE OF HUMOR. The man was very, very funny - he just didn’t show it much.

“Limelight” pretty much defined his attitude toward fame, and you really can’t blame him, as talented as he was.

The boy is right, and as easy as it is to fall into grief, his music and talent and words will live on forever, and we should celebrate that.

RIP, Professor. You are missed.

snippet.textDisplay:
When I was 3 years old, I got my first drum set for Christmas. When I first sat down at it, I didn't play a thing, I just sat their staring at it. This went on for five minutes until my parents asked me what I was doing. I said I was imagining I was Neil Peart, getting ready to start his next solo. When I heard of the news of Neil's passing, I immediately went back to my music room, and sat down at that same drum set. As I did that, I imagined Neil doing the same thing up in the sky, starting his next solo.
Neil Peart was the reason that I started playing drums.
Thank you for posting this, Rick.

snippet.textDisplay: Back in the late '70s, I was a youngster in junior high, and had been taking drum lessons for 3-4 years. My older brother got the Rush Archives album for Christmas, and I couldn't believe what I was hearing... a myriad of rudimentary fills with rolls, flams, paradiddles, hi hat barks, double kicks, all arranged in endlessly creative patterns against hard rock music. It was so innovative and so groundbreaking at the time, and this was when Rush was a power rock trio without keyboards... props to Neil for defining his own "hard prog rock" sound and taking rock drumming to entirely different level. I believe he changed rock drumming forever.

snippet.textDisplay: I was also very shocked to learn of his passing.  Never even knew he was battling cancer.  But that is Neil's personality to not want people to be sorry for him, or be cast in the spotlight.  The guy was just happy to be behind the drum kit, and the fame and fortune that came with it was just a benefit.  He truly was the most influential percussionist of the last 40+ years, and about every modern rock/metal drummer that we love were built from the foundation that Neil set.  Really the saddest thing to happen in the Rock/Metal era to happen since losing Dimebag Darrell and Vinnie Paul as far as musicians go.  Obviously, losing Chris Cornell and Chester Bennington were huge blows as well.  Fly high Neil!  At least now he can be with his wife and daughter again.

Neil's book Ghost Rider got my through some tough times. For me, it's easier to bear pain when you hear about another's pain. Prayers to his wife and daughter to overcome this major loss.

snippet.textDisplay:
You have got to feel in some way uplifted... loss is always tough to deal with, but to see so many saddened people up and down the globe, so much love, respect, admiration, so many baffled people feeling like we've lost a family member or a very dear close friend. 
To know that one human being was able to reach such levels of perfection, such excellence and affected so many people for the better... and finally, if it's any consolation, to know he is no longer in any pain or suffering in any way... for me it's my way of finding peace... because it truly feels like the loss of a brother... finally for all his talent and creativity, this will always remain a mantra in my life: "I don't have faith in faith, I don't believe in belief, you can call me faithless, I still cling to hope, and I believe in love, and that's faith enough for me"... Farewell and godspeed, friend.

snippet.textDisplay:
I, personally feel grateful that we were able to be alive and know the majesty that was and always will be RUSH.

Some people laughed at or scoffed us for our musical preference; they didn’t get it. Some never will. That’s okay. WE did... WE were the lucky ones!!

Many of us invested (1980 for me) years of our life with this band, some more some less; but we were nonetheless in their club. RUSH included us... we were RUSH!!

Whether they knew it or not, RUSH has been with all of us through our good days and our bad ones too.

They helped us celebrate our victories and defeats. They were there during famine or feast.

... and WE will always love you and be with you, Closer to our Hearts.

snippet.textDisplay: Back in 1974, I was probably one of the first 500 people in the States to even know who RUSH was.  Played their first record after a friend loaned it to me from elementary school.  We were out on the playground talking about our RUSH, KISS, Zep and Aerosmith records.  We were just punk kids.  Nobody knew who RUSH was except us.  Here we are today, some 45 years later--still celebrating and appreciating the wonders of this band.  Through the years, I have enjoyed playing some of the RUSH songs on bass guitar and drums.  My life would not have been the same without their music.  Those three guys are/were a class act that will never be matched.  Glad to have seen them at three concerts, with my very first concert of any group in 1980--during the Permanent Waves tour.  R.I.P. Neil.  We will always miss and remember you dearly.

snippet.textDisplay: Many kindred spirits showing up around the world when it comes to Neil and Rush in general.   Even more than I would have expected, and so many feeling a real sense of personal loss.   A 40 year drum idol and influencer for me is gone, but will be remembered and enjoyed always through Rush’s timeless and magical music.   The list of my (top tier) drumming idols is sadly getting shorter.   Bonham, Porcaro and now Peart.   May Gadd and Colaiuta live on for many years to come.  Thanks for everything you do, Rick.   Myself, and my 10 year old guitar playing son both love your shows.   I think he’s becoming addicted.   RIP Neil Peart

snippet.textDisplay: Whether or not you liked their music, Rush was always creative, authentic, evolving, and were masters of their respective instruments. Beyond that, in an industry where most bands end up infighting, they exemplified the spirit of a band of best friends who loved each other's company, even after 30 years of working together. Peart's lyrics spoke to a lot of people for good reason, he always felt to me like a voice for the quiet, reflective introverts out there. When I listen to his words I always feel like they just "get" me, and that I'm at home. The fact that they were from my own hometown was the cherry on top of it all. A big loss for sure, but on the other hand Neil has left an incredible, positive mark on the world, which I believe is what he aspired to do with his time on Earth.

snippet.textDisplay: I'll be 57 in March and since before I was a teen I have worshipped this man and this band. Neil has been my idol for over 40 years, so, needless to say, this hit me devastatingly hard. It is the first time I've ever openly wept due to the passing of a rock legend. I'm not ashamed, nor do I care about admitting it. It goes well beyond mere music or idolizing someone. It is personal when if affects so many aspects and eras of your life to such degrees. I've seen an outpouring of emotion online the likes of which I've never seen before from both the music community and fan bases. People who aren't even drummers or musicians have been touched by this musical wizard. I've no doubt that this wound will never quite heal and that, for as long as a lot of we fans live, this will leave a formidable scar. Every time I allow myself to really think about what Neil has meant to me, I break down. He was so very important to me, and I'd surmise to millions of others. The realization and that life simply passes too quickly becomes all the more real when the heroes we grew up with begin passing. This is the end of an era I must to come to grips with even though my heart will not allow my head to wrap itself around the notion that gentle souls must too make the journey. And so I will allow my pain and my tears to be Neil's legacy for this moment. Farewell, Neil Peart. I love you, Sir.

snippet.textDisplay:
Really nice heart felt tribute guys.
I have never met Neil, and I have never even had the opportunity to see Rush live, but I feel such a sense of loss with Neil's passing. He was one of my drumming inspirations and I am still blown away by some of the stuff he came up with on Fly By Night, let alone the body of work that spanned the wonderful career of Rush. His lyrics were so intimate and connected with me on many levels. Neil's integrity, drive, and commitment, set him apart from many of his peers, and Rush as a band have a history of being a pure class act throughout their long journey together. His reputation and musical contributions will live on. Thanks Neil.

snippet.textDisplay: It honestly explained a lot when I heard he’d been battling a Glioblastoma for the last 3 years. Even with modern medical tech, that’s a death sentence, and he made it twice as long as average. I’m not surprised he wanted to keep it private, and there had been nothing at all from him in at least 3 years. I expected to at least see more books from him or activity on his blog, or possibly a new album from Rush (even though it wouldn’t include a tour) but now it makes sense.

snippet.textDisplay: When I was in high school, I had friends who were drummers and they would boast all the time about learning to play new songs from Metallica, Megadeth, Slayer, etc., but the inevitable question that always came up was 'Yes, but can you play La Villa Strangiato?', that told me everything about who actual drummers thought was the greatest.
